subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... If I only write new code when a test is failing, I should never have an untested path in new code. Examples to the contrary welcome. Mike -- Mike Clark
messageBody:
Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>
> > Isn't it sufficient to test that you get the correct return value for
> > whatever combinations of input values you choose to test with?
>
> yes and no. writing tests does not guarantee that you have tested all
> paths. And since it's impossible to test every input values, a good
> alternative is to choose the input value that give you the most feedback.
>

If I only write new code when a test is failing, I should never have an
untested path in new code.

Examples to the contrary welcome.

Mike

--
Mike Clark
Clarkware Consulting, Inc.
http://www.clarkware.com
720.851.2014
